obi:BFO_0000066.dcterms:name: bone marrow
obi:BFO_0000066.dcterms:description: The paper discusses clonal hematopoiesis occurring in blood-forming tissues, particularly in the context of Bloom syndrome patients and carriers.

obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:name: DNA repair
obi:BFO_0000050.dcterms:description: The BLM gene discussed in the paper codes for a DNA helicase that is crucial for DNA repair processes.

obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:name: hematopoietic stem cell proliferation
obi:RO_0002304.dcterms:description: The paper describes how mutations in DNA repair genes affect clonal expansion of hematopoietic cells.

obi:RO_0002629.dcterms:name: cellular aging
obi:RO_0002629.dcterms:description: The study mentions how telomere maintenance genes are associated with the prevalence of clonal hematopoiesis.

obi:RO_0002305.dcterms:name: cell proliferation
obi:RO_0002305.dcterms:description: The paper discusses how defects in DNA damage response (through BLM mutations) lead to increased cellular proliferation and cancer risk.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: Bloom syndrome
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Characterized by growth restriction, sun sensitivity, insulin resistance, mild immune deficiency, and increased risk of early-onset malignancy. 53% of participants had developed cancer, with hematologic malignancies being the most common cancer risk. Study found both Bloom syndrome patients and BLM carriers exhibited increased frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential (CHIP) compared to controls.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: leukemia
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: CHIP is associated with an annual increased risk of leukemia ranging from 0.5% to 1.0%. In the study cohort, some patients developed various types of leukemia including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukemia (AML) post sample collection.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: colorectal cancer
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Recent studies have identified increased risk of colorectal cancer in BLM pathogenic variant carriers.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: breast cancer
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Recent studies have identified increased risk of breast cancer in BLM pathogenic variant carriers.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: mesothelioma
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: Recent studies have identified increased risk of mesothelioma in BLM pathogenic variant carriers.

obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:title: DNA
obi:OBI_0000299.dcterms:description: DNA variants were analyzed from peripheral blood samples, with variant allele frequencies (VAF) below 0.3 indicating acquired somatic variants, while VAF greater than or equal to 0.3 indicated likely germline or de novo variants

dcterms:hasPart: A research paper examining hematopoiesis within blood forming tissues particularly in Bloom syndrome patients and carriers reveals significant findings about DNA repair and cellular processes The study focuses on how the BLM gene which codes for a DNA helicase affects DNA repair processes and influences clonal hematopoiesis Mutations in DNA repair genes are shown to impact the clonal expansion of hematopoietic cells while telomere maintenance genes are linked to clonal hematopoiesis prevalence The research demonstrates that defects in DNA damage response caused by BLM mutations lead to increased cellular proliferation and elevated cancer risk Bloom syndrome is characterized by growth restriction sun sensitivity insulin resistance mild immune deficiency and increased risk of early onset malignancy with 53 percent of study participants developing cancer predominantly hematologic malignancies Both Bloom syndrome patients and BLM carriers showed higher frequency of clonal hematopoiesis of indeterminate potential CHIP compared to control groups CHIP is associated with an annual increased leukemia risk of 0 5 to 1 0 percent with some patients developing acute lymphoblastic leukemia ALL and acute myeloid leukemia AML after sample collection Recent studies have identified increased risks of colorectal cancer breast cancer and mesothelioma in BLM pathogenic variant carriers DNA analysis from peripheral blood samples was conducted with variant allele frequencies VAF below 0 3 indicating acquired somatic variants while VAF greater than or equal to 0 3 suggested likely germline or de novo variants The research highlights the interconnected nature of DNA repair mechanisms cellular aging hematopoietic stem cell proliferation and cancer development in the context of Bloom syndrome and BLM mutations
